Forecasts assume that large projects like Northern Metropolis will reduce unemployment in the late 2020s and early 2030s and demographic ageing will also keep unemployment low. Also: 3% is very near frictional levels anyway and it realistically can't go very much lower.

Presuming import prices also relate to imports of Chinese goods for re-export elsewhere, and these may lower their prices in view of the huge tariffs?

replies.content: Yes agreed. All else equal % change in import & import+re-export prices for these should be very correlated. Perhaps slightly less for locally consumed imports since less additional costs (e.g, shipping) which are also subject to trade tensions. I see this also assumes trade tensions getting worse this year, then improving from  2026

comments.content: Please check nominal GDP carefully. I have no idea how to forecast this. We didn't have to do this before. My only assumption is that the growth rate of nominal GDP should be something like the sum of GDP growth and CPI, roughly.

Stocks are the only row here I added in residuals all the way to 2050. This is because i didn't want stocks zooming up to over 50, and I felt some negative years were appropriate too. Should the gap between the real and nominal number get wider over time due to inflation? Please confirm my forecast is OK.

replies.content: Yes. The difference in growth rates of these is inflation

comments.content: https://www.budget.gov.hk/2025/eng/pdf/e_appendices_a.pdf This is bond issuance in the year in USD, see p7. Assuming it is all intenrational investor who buy it.
I don't know why it was zero before, but HK up until a few years ago didn't have much debt, but they're getting into it in a big way now.

Up 13.1% yoy in BOP in Q1, and customs figures for Jan-May show exports up by 12.6% yoy, so even if some exports have been shifted forward, there is no room for panic over the tariff dispute. HK trade organisations admit trade will slow a lot on the remainder of 2025: https://www.thestandard.com.hk/hong-kong-news/article/305918/Hong-Kong-exports-to-slow-in-rest-of-2025-industrial-leader-Wingco-Lo-says
Up 12.5% in BOP terms in Q1, and cutoms figures show 12.9% incxrease yoy on Jan-May. Will slow a lot in the rest of the  year.
